+package globalrolesv2
+
+import (
+	"testing"
+
+	"github.com/rancher/rancher/tests/framework/clients/rancher"
+	management "github.com/rancher/rancher/tests/framework/clients/rancher/generated/management/v3"
+	"github.com/rancher/rancher/tests/framework/extensions/clusters"
+	"github.com/rancher/rancher/tests/framework/pkg/session"
+
+	"github.com/stretchr/testify/require"
+	"github.com/stretchr/testify/suite"
+
+	"github.com/rancher/rancher/tests/framework/extensions/kubeapi/rbac"
+	"github.com/rancher/rancher/tests/framework/extensions/users"
+	namegen "github.com/rancher/rancher/tests/framework/pkg/namegenerator"
+	log "github.com/sirupsen/logrus"
+	"github.com/stretchr/testify/assert"
+	metav1 "k8s.io/apimachinery/pkg/apis/meta/v1"
+	"k8s.io/apimachinery/pkg/labels"
+	"k8s.io/apimachinery/pkg/selection"
+)
+
+type GlobalRolesV2TestSuite struct {
+	suite.Suite
+	client      *rancher.Client
+	session     *session.Session
+	cluster     *management.Cluster
+	clusterName string
+	clusterID   string
+
+}
+
+func (gr *GlobalRolesV2TestSuite) TearDownSuite() {
+	gr.session.Cleanup()
+}
+
+func (gr *GlobalRolesV2TestSuite) SetupSuite() {
+	testSession := session.NewSession()
+	gr.session = testSession
+
+	client, err := rancher.NewClient("", testSession)
+	require.NoError(gr.T(), err)
+
+	gr.client = client
+	gr.clusterName = client.RancherConfig.ClusterName
+	require.NotEmptyf(gr.T(), gr.clusterName, "Cluster name to install should be set")
+	gr.clusterID, err = clusters.GetClusterIDByName(gr.client, gr.clusterName)
+	require.NoError(gr.T(), err, "Error getting cluster ID")
+	gr.cluster, err = gr.client.Management.Cluster.ByID(gr.clusterID)
+	require.NoError(gr.T(), err)
+
+}
+
+// func (gr *GlobalRolesV2TestSuite) sequentialTestGlobalRolesV2() {
+// 	validaGlobalRoleWithInheritedClusterRole(gr.T(), gr.clusterName, gr.client)
+// }
+
+func (gr *GlobalRolesV2TestSuite) TestGlobalRolesV2() {
+	subSession := gr.session.NewSession()
+	defer subSession.Cleanup()
+
+	globalRole.Name = namegen.AppendRandomString("testgr-")
+	globalRole.InheritedClusterRoles = append(globalRole.InheritedClusterRoles, roleOwner)
+	createdRole, err := rbac.CreateGlobalRole(gr.client, localcluster, &globalRole)
+	require.NoError(gr.T(), err)
+	createUser, err := users.CreateUserWithRole(gr.client, users.UserConfig(), standardUser, createdRole.Name)
+
+	require.NoError(gr.T(), err)
+
+	log.Info("Verify the global role binding is created for the user")
+	grblist, err := rbac.ListGlobalRoleBindings(gr.client, localcluster, metav1.ListOptions{})
+
+	require.NoError(gr.T(), err)
+
+	var grbOwner string
+	for _, grbs := range grblist.Items {
comment.body: Field selectors are not supported for username or globalRoleName fields in globalrolebindings.

issue.title: [RFE] Proxy HTTP requests via Rancher

labels.name: kind/enhancement
labels.description: Issues that improve or augment existing functionality

issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
- The Rancher UI, specifically extensions, need to make http requests to endpoints other than Rancher
- Endpoints can be in flux and will change given things like extensions installed, clusters the user has visibility of, etc
- Some of these requests require authentication in a number of ways (auth header, creds in body, etc)

**Describe the solution you'd like**
In terms of requirements, the solution should cover...

- UI needs to proxy requests to pseudo ad-hoc endpoints 
  - The endpoints will change given things like visible clusters e.g. Epinio needs to proxy requests to a cluster that has Epinio installed. New clusters could be brought up, user could gain permissions to see a cluster with epinio in, etc
- User can manage credentials for an endpoint
  - This links credentials to a specific endpoint
  - Users can create, see and delete their credentials
    - Users should not be able to see the sensitive information (password, token, etc)
  - Credentials should be safely stored in Rancher
    - Administrators should not be able to see other peoples credentials
    - We should take steps to protect username / password credentials from being viewed
      - encrypted such that they are not easily decipherable?
      - if resource based hide them from everything except an operator?
- Proxy requests with credentials for auth
    - If a credential id is specified at request time the proxy applies them to the proxied request via either
      - authentication header
      - custom header (random-header-name-1: value from credentials).
      - inserting into the proxied request itself (e.g. add password field into a request body JSON)
- Should be possible to communicate with an endpoint using self-signed certificate (does not currently support this)

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
There is an existing mechanism `meta/proxy` that covers some of the requirements, however it has limitations
- Depends on a static `whitelist-domain` (or node driver white list magic)
- It's heavily tied to cluster / node drivers
  - A `cloudcredential`, who's id is supplied to `meta/proxy `, cannot be created without a cluster / node driver `config` property
- When applying cloudcredential values they're just set in the auth header
- Cannot proxy to endpoints with an unsigned cert


**Additional context**
Use Cases
- Rancher UI has the Epinio Extension installed. The extension needs to communicate with an Epinio instance. The Epinio instance requires a basic auth header containing username and password. In order to avoid the user having to enter these credentials on every load of the Rancher UI they need to be persisted somewhere safe and applied to proxied API requests
- As per above, but for the SUSE Manager UI extension communicating with SUSE Manager
- Openstack UI extension proxies requests to Openstack API and needs to insert credentials into the body
https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/pike/api_curl_examples.html
- KubeWarden UI Extension proxies requests to [artifacthub.io](http://artifacthub.io/)

pull_request.title: fix test to work with rancher envs without cert
pull_request.body:
## Issue: <!-- link the issue or issues this PR resolves here -->
<!-- If your PR depends on changes from another pr link them here and describe why they are needed on your solution section. -->
 
## Problem
<!-- Describe the root cause of the issue you are resolving. This may include what behavior is observed and why it is not desirable. If this is a new feature describe why we need this feature and how it will be used. -->

The problem was that when creating this test I personally only use Rancher setups with certs. However, if someone runs this on a Rancher setup without certs it doesn't execute the test
 
## Solution
<!-- Describe what you changed to fix the issue. Relate your changes back to the original issue / feature and explain why this addresses the issue. -->

Add a step to check if we need to skip cert verification

```go
	if skipCertVerification {
		tr.TLSClientConfig = &tls.Config{InsecureSkipVerify: true}
	}
```
 
## Engineering Testing
### Manual Testing
<!-- Describe what manual testing you did (if no testing was done, explain why). -->

### Automated Testing
<!-- Ensure there are unit/integration/validation tests added (if possible); describe what cases they cover and do not cover. -->

issue.title: [BUG] Prometheus Federator

labels.name: kind/bug
labels.description: Issues that are defects reported by users or that we know have reached a real release

issue.body:
**Rancher Server Setup**
- Rancher version: v2.8-head/v2.8-alpha2
- Installation option (Docker install/Helm Chart): Docker

**Information about the Cluster**
- Kubernetes version: v1.27.6-rancher1-1
- Cluster Type (Local/Downstream): Hardened RKE1 Downstream 
   - If downstream, what type of cluster? (Custom/Imported or specify provider for Hosted/Infrastructure Provider): AWS Node Driver

**User Information**
- What is the role of the user logged in? - Admin

**Describe the bug**
<!--A clear and concise description of what the bug is.-->
Project registration namespace is not locked. If user edits the `field.cattle.io/projectId` label number a new namespace gets created. "`Not in a Project`"

**To Reproduce**

- Create a rancher server v2.8.0-alpha2
- Provision a downstream RKE1 cluster v1.27.6. (2cp, 3etcd, 3 worker nodes)
- Install Monitoring and Prometheus Federator charts.
- Create a new Project ex. test-project
  - Create a new namespace in a test-project e.g. test-ns
  - Another namespace (Project Registration Namespace) should get created in test-project (cattle-project-p-ID) (ID is randomaly generated string) 
- Edit the label `field.cattle.io/projectId` in namespace test-ns.
- Make sure the change made is reverted.

**Result**
- Notice a new namespace gets created under "`Not in a Project`"

**Expected Result**
Change made in the label is reverted back to original label and new namespace should not get created.

**Additional context**
This issue was encountered while testing Prometheus Federator support for k8s v1.27. - https://github.com/rancher/rancher/issues/41784

issue.title: Cannot setup custom CIS benchmarks in Rancher 2.6.11/12/13 and in Rancher 2.7.3
issue.body:
Issue description: Setting up a custom cis benchmark following the [documentation](https://ranchermanager.docs.rancher.com/v2.6/integrations-in-rancher/cis-scans/custom-benchmark), It ends up with a scan that does not work.

Business impact:
Cannot create custom cis benchmarks with CIS Operator

Troubleshooting steps:
Config files downloaded from: [Aqua](https://github.com/aquasecurity/kube-bench/tree/main/cfg)

Repro steps:

- Download all cis version yamls from [Aqua](https://github.com/aquasecurity/kube-bench/tree/main/cfg/cis-1.23)
- Add the target_mapping to the config.yaml for the custom configuration
- Create the custom configmap with all required yamls
 
```
±|master ✗|→ kubectl get nodes
NAME   STATUS   ROLES                      AGE    VERSION
2      Ready    controlplane,etcd,worker   5d1h   v1.22.13
±|master ✗|→ kubectl create cm custom-benchmark --from-file=custom-benchmark
configmap/custom-benchmark created
±|master ✗|→ kubectl get cm
NAME               DATA   AGE
custom-benchmark   6      13s
kube-root-ca.crt   1      5d1h
```
 
- Create a new benchmark from Rancher UI on a downstream cluster using the UI
- Create a new profile and a new CIS Scan. The scan does not complete and the sonobuoy pod for the custom scan goes into Error /Crashloopbackoff status.

Workaround:
Is a workaround available and implemented? no
What is the workaround:

**Actual behavior**: 
The scan runs but endlessly and the generated sonobuoy container goes into CrashloopBackoff with an error, that cannot write the output to /tmp/out/sonobuoy.error

**Expected behavior**:
Custom CIS scan works fine

SURE-6611

comment.body:
I just tested with the given config.yaml. It's working fine. 
I see the profile name mentioned in config.yaml under "target_mapping" is tkgi-1.2.53 but you're creating the benchmark version with the name "test-benchmark". This is where the problem happening. 
The benchmark version name should be same as the profile name mentioned under "target_mapping" in config.yaml.

issue.title: [BUG]error running the jail command: exit status 1

labels.name: kind/bug
labels.description: Issues that are defects reported by users or that we know have reached a real release

issue.body:
**Rancher Server Setup**
- Rancher version: v2.6.3
- Installation option (Docker install/Helm Chart):
   - Docker Install 

Build and run environment: ubuntu 20.04 / docker version 20.10.10, ubuntu 18.04 / docker 20.10.9
Build command: make
Run command: docker run -d --restart=unless-stopped -p 80:80 -p 443:443 --privileged rancher/rancher:dev

What I edited
script/ci
"./validate" and "./test" remove

package/Dockerfile
153 Line ARG VERSION=dev => ARG VERSION=v2.6.3

I have been building and using rancher/server myself since two years ago.
I was using it well until the beginning of this year, but recently the container is not running.
The build is successful, but the container continues to restart when running docker run.
If you check with docker log, the [FATAL] error running the jail command: exit status 1 log is repeated.

The previous version, v2.4.3, can be built and run.
However, the version used, v2.6.3, does not run.

issue.title: [BUG] KubeConfig generated by Rancher uses wrong certificate-authority-data

labels.name: kind/bug
labels.description: Issues that are defects reported by users or that we know have reached a real release

issue.body:
**Rancher Server Setup**
- Rancher version:  v2.7.6
- Installation option:  Helm Chart
   - k3s 1.26.9+k3s1
- Proxy/Cert Details:  See bug notes below

**Information about the Cluster**
- Kubernetes version:  1.26.9+k3s1
- Cluster Type (Local/Downstream):  Local (but custom clusters built from Rancher exhibit the same issue)

**User Information**
- What is the role of the user logged in?  Admin


**Describe the bug**
A 3 node k3s cluster was created and cert-manager was installed.  A ClusterIssuer was created for Let's Encrypt production using the DNS-01 solver (since our cluster is on-premise without external access).  A certificate for rancher.<domain>.com was requested and successfully generated and saved in the tls-rancher-ingress secret in the cattle-system namespace.  Rancher was then installed via Helm with the hostname set to rancher.<domain>.com and the ingress.tls.source set to secret.  Rancher successfully installed and I am able to access Rancher via https://rancher.<domain>.com with a production Let's Encrypt certificate and no errors.  I was able to also successfully create a k3s cluster through Rancher on another set of nodes without any issues.

However, within Rancher, when I click on the Download KubeConfig button (or the "Copy KubeConfig to Clipboard" button, the KubeConfig that is generated includes the wrong certificate-authority-data.  Specifically, after decoding the data in the KubeConfig file, it appears the certificate is coming from either the automatically created tls-rancher or tls-rancher-internal-ca secrets (as the domain name is dynamiclistener-ca@xxxxx with a matching expiration date to the secret).  This happens for both "Download KubeConfig" in the local cluster and a downstream cluster.

Attempting to kubectl get nodes with this KubeConfig file generates a "certificate signed by unknown authority" error.  Using --insecure-skip-tls-verify allows kubectl to work, which makes sense (but certainly isn't ideal).  Manually modifying the KubeConfig file to replace the "certificate-authority-data" with the correct CA data (from the tls-rancher-ingress secret) also allows kubectl to work, but the Download KubeConfig button in Rancher should just use the correct certificate-authority-data in the first place.

**To Reproduce**
1) Confirm the Rancher web UI is working correctly with a production Let's Encrypt generated certificate (without TLS errors), which was generated through Cert-Manager (installed before Rancher) and saved as tls-rancher-ingress in the cattle-system namespace, with Rancher installed with the correct hostname and ingress.tls.source set to secret.
2) Click Download KubeConfig in the Rancher UI.

**Result**
Kubectl complains about certificate issues with the downloaded KubeConfig, since it's using the wrong CA information.

**Expected Result**
"Download KubeConfig" should use the CA information from the tls-rancher-ingress secret.

**Screenshots**
tls-ran secrets in the cattle-system namespace
![image](https://github.com/rancher/rancher/assets/66883280/59ef6c01-bfdf-4a00-be86-69bf42383b69)

CA information in "Download KubeConfig" config file decoded
![image](https://github.com/rancher/rancher/assets/66883280/5d1aecac-47f0-44ce-a2bf-b140cf2335c0)

CA information in proper CA from actual certificate decoded
![image](https://github.com/rancher/rancher/assets/66883280/ceb95074-d747-4fdc-ada0-a20579bd494f)

comment.body: This repository uses an automated workflow to automatically label pull requests which have not had any activity (commit/comment/label) for 60 days. This helps us manage the community pull requests better. If the pull request is still relevant, please add a comment to the pull request so the workflow can remove the label and we know it is still valid. If it is no longer relevant (or possibly fixed in the latest release), the workflow will automatically close the pull request in 14 days. Thank you for your contributions.

issue.title: [BUG] Removing/dropping env var item from the `extra_env` list of any kube components does not take effect on worker nodes on RKE1 node-driver clusters

labels.name: kind/bug
labels.description: Issues that are defects reported by users or that we know have reached a real release

issue.body:
**Rancher Server Setup**
- Rancher version: v2.7.3 , but any 
- Installation option (Docker install/Helm Chart): any 
   - If Helm Chart, Kubernetes Cluster and version (RKE1, RKE2, k3s, EKS, etc):
- Proxy/Cert Details:

**Information about the Cluster**
- Kubernetes version: v1.24.17, but any 
- Cluster Type (Local/Downstream):
   - If downstream, what type of cluster? (Custom/Imported or specify provider for Hosted/Infrastructure Provider): RKE1 node-driver downstream cluster 
<!--
* Custom = Running a docker command on a node
* Imported = Running kubectl apply onto an existing k8s cluster
* Hosted = EKS, GKE, AKS, etc
 * Infrastructure Provider = Rancher provisioning the nodes using different node drivers (e.g. AWS, Digital Ocean, etc)
-->

**User Information**
- What is the role of the user logged in? (Admin/Cluster Owner/Cluster Member/Project Owner/Project Member/Custom)
  - If custom, define the set of permissions: admin 



**Describe the bug**
<!--A clear and concise description of what the bug is.-->

In Rancher, we can set extra environment variables for kube components, such as kubelet, kube-apisever, etc., on RKE1 node-driver clusters. 

The bug is that the extra env var is not removed from the underlying running container on **worker nodes** if we remove it later. 

It happens because the Rancher Node Agent fails to detect the change in the node plan. Therefore, it does not recreate the corresponding container. As a result, even if the Node object says the new node plan is applied ( value of the field `.Status.NodePlan.Plan`), it is actually the old one being used, at least for the containers whose only env var is changed in the new node plan. 

The bug happens only on worker-only nodes on the RKE1 node-driver cluster.


**To Reproduce**
<!--Steps to reproduce the behavior-->

- provision a downstream RKE1 cluster: 1 etcd, 1 control plane, 2 workers. 
- edit the cluster as YAML to add the following extra env var to kubelet 
```
rancher_kubernetes_engine_config:
  services:
    kubelet:
      extra_env:
        - extra_env-1=val-1
        - extra_env-2=env-val-2
```
- save and wait for the cluster to be ready again 
- ssh into the worker node, and do `docker inspect kubelet` to check the value of `Env`.  The result should be similar to  the following 
```
            "Env": [
                "extra_env-1=val-1",
                "extra_env-2=env-val-2",
                "RKE_KUBELET_CRIDOCKERD=true",
                "PATH=/usr/local/sbin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/sbin:/usr/bin:/sbin:/bin"
            ],
```
- Edit the cluster again to drop  the 2nd env var `extra_env-2=env-val-2` 
- save and wait for the cluster to be ready again 
- ssh into the worker node, and do `docker inspect kubelet` to check the value of `Env`. 


**Result**

1. The same env vars are applied on the kubelet container; `extra_env-2=env-val-2` is NOT dropped. 
2. The result of `docker ps`  indicates the kubelet was not recreated by its creation time and uptime. 


**Expected Result**
<!--A clear and concise description of what you expected to happen.-->

The kubelet container should be recreated based on the new nod plan, ie. the Env should not contain `extra_env-2=env-val-2`.

**Additional context**
In the following logic, it fails to check the case where an env var is removed because it is not in the `expectedEnvs`: 
https://github.com/rancher/rancher/blob/ba30c1c31ee2ea04c901de1c4e0346da53c30dc3/pkg/rkeworker/docker.go#L260-L273

pull_request.title: fix typo in filename
pull_request.body: PR to fix typo in filename
